instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1534: What is A1534? A1534 is a model number for a 12 inch size Macbook  from years 2015, 2016 with EMC 2746, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00045, 820-00244..
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.820-00244: What is 820-00244? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PPVCORE_S0_CPU: What is PPVCORE_S0_CPU? This is the primary power rail for the CPU that powers the CPU, known as CPU vcore. Without this, the machine will be braindead. .
definitions.PLT_RESET_L: What is PLT_RESET_L? PLT_RESET_L is platform reset, this signal keeps the system from POSTing. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> power cycling
threads.message:
Hey guys

Got <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>(<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>) that is power cycling.
Takes 19-20V from the charger but cycles between 0A -> 240mA -> 415mA -> 0A

Bought it as broken, for parts. Someone took it apart before, stripped screws, stripped screw holes and metal shavings on the board.
Nosigns of any rework done on it. 

Signs of liquid damage, tiny spots of corrosion, darkened caps below <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>(<CAPACITOR>C7016</CAPACITOR>, <CAPACITOR>C7028</CAPACITOR>, <CAPACITOR>C7012</CAPACITOR>, <CAPACITOR>C7017</CAPACITOR>)
<CAPACITOR>C9300</CAPACITOR> below <CHIP>U3700</CHIP> looks dark/corroded - it's for <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> -> ground. But its not shorted, nothing is shorted.

I want to ask for opinion before I start looking for replacement caps. No clue if that might be the problem.

I took off and reballed <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> and <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> because I noticed signs of liquid being under the chips at some point.

I went through every single power rail. 
Only these are not correct values - rest (every single one)just goes to specified value and drops down to zero. Nothing stays on permanently.
<SIGNAL>PP3V3R2V7_NAND_VCC</SIGNAL> - 2.8V (3.3V in schematics)
<SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> - 1.32V - 0.74V (1.8V)
<SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_GT</SIGNAL> - 0.0V (1.8V) (3.9 Ohm - from what I understand CPU rails are always low resistance)
<SIGNAL>PPVCORE_SUS_PCH</SIGNAL> - 1V (1.8V)

Thank in advance

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> power cycling
threads.message:
Voltages did not catch nominal value, because of cycling power.
<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> is the worst machine made by Apple.
Very high-density board, liquid spill is almost letal.
I do not recommend to waste time on it.
CPU and SSD failures are classic problems.

Check if stays on in SMC bypass mode.
<SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL> pulsing too?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> power cycling
threads.message: Yeah, got it cheaply tho. I'sorry but I don't know what is SMC bypass mode
